content:
Let C\mathcal{C}C be category and F:C→CF:\mathcal{C} \rightarrow \mathcal{C}F:C→C an endofunctor.

Then, I can obtain a new category CF\mathcal{C}_FCF​ as follows:

  • Ob(CF)=Ob(C)\mathrm{Ob}(\mathcal{C}_F)=\mathrm{Ob}(\mathcal{C})Ob(CF​)=Ob(C),
  • CF[A,B]=C[F(A),F(B)]\mathcal{C}_F[A,B]=\mathcal{C}[F(A),F(B)]CF​[A,B]=C[F(A),F(B)],
  • if v∈CF[B,C]v \in \mathcal{C}_F[B,C]v∈CF​[B,C] and u∈CF[A,B]u \in \mathcal{C}_F[A,B]u∈CF​[A,B], then v∘CFu=v∘uv \circ^{\mathcal{C}_F} u = v \circ uv∘CF​u=v∘u,
  • idACF=idF(A)\mathrm{id}^{\mathcal{C}_F}_A = \mathrm{id}_{F(A)}idACF​​=idF(A)​.

It seems to me that it is similar to the idea of a Kleisli category but without assuming than the endofunctor is a monad, and even simpler that the category of algebras over an endofunctor. Somehow, the simplest category you can create from an endofunctor.

Does it have a name?

Hmm I'm unsure if I didn't want to write instead:

  • CF[A,B]={F(f), f∈C[A,B]}\mathcal{C}^F[A,B]=\{F(f),~f \in \mathcal{C}[A,B]\}CF[A,B]={F(f), f∈C[A,B]}
The first version you posted is simply the factorization of FFF into a bijective-on-objects followed by a fully-faithful functor. It doesn't have anything to do with FFF being an endofunctor.
The second version won't work, since images of functors are not always subcategories.

By construction, the functor C→\mathcal{C} \to C→ {your category} is bijective on objects. This category arises in a certain sense as a Kleisli category: it's related to the Kleisli category of the codensity monad of F

Kevin Carlson said:

The second version won't work, since images of functors are not always subcategories.

What do you mean? F(f)∘F(g)=F(f∘g)F(f) \circ F(g)=F(f \circ g)F(f)∘F(g)=F(f∘g), where is the issue?
(is it the same thing? Don't remember now)
fff and ggg aren't necessarily composable just because F(f)F(f)F(f) and F(g)F(g)F(g) are!
Consider the functor from the disjoint union of two walking arrows that glues one domain to one codomain. The resulting quotient is a 2-simplex but the long arrow of the 2-simplex isn't in the image.

Jean-Baptiste Vienney said:

Kevin Carlson said:

The second version won't work, since images of functors are not always subcategories.

What do you mean? F(f)∘F(g)=F(f∘g)F(f) \circ F(g)=F(f \circ g)F(f)∘F(g)=F(f∘g), where is the issue?

The issue is that if $$f,g$ are composable then Ff,FgFf, FgFf,Fg are; not viceversa. For example, take a constant functor onto a single object, f,gf,gf,g in two disconnected components of the domain category...
I see what you mean but I wrote that a morphism from AAA to BBB in the new category if of the form F(f)F(f)F(f) where fff is necessarily from AAA to BBB.
I don't ask just that it is of the form F(f):F(A)→F(B)F(f):F(A) \rightarrow F(B)F(f):F(A)→F(B) for any morphism fff.

Jean-Baptiste Vienney said:

It seems to me that it is similar to the idea of a Kleisli category but without assuming than the endofunctor is a monad

As Kevin has pointed out, the original definition is the [[full image]] of FFF. However, there's a reason it looks similar to a Kleisli category: it is precisely the Kleisli category for FFF viewed as an FFF- [[relative monad]].
Woh, very cool!
So an endofunctor FFF is a always an FFF-relative monad?

Jean-Baptiste Vienney said:

I see what you mean but I wrote that a morphism from AAA to BBB in the new category if of the form F(f)F(f)F(f) where fff is necessarily from AAA to BBB.

Does it solve the issue, or am I still misunderstanding?
Ok, I see the issue.

fosco said:

Jean-Baptiste Vienney said:

Kevin Carlson said:

The second version won't work, since images of functors are not always subcategories.

What do you mean? F(f)∘F(g)=F(f∘g)F(f) \circ F(g)=F(f \circ g)F(f)∘F(g)=F(f∘g), where is the issue?

The issue is that if $$f,g$ are composable then Ff,FgFf, FgFf,Fg are; not viceversa. For example, take a constant functor onto a single object, f,gf,gf,g in two disconnected components of the domain category...

Argh, no I still don't understand. I think this is a subcategory of the first one and I could even get a bigger one by writing CF[A,B]={F(f):F(A)→F(B), f∈C[X,Y], X,Y∈Ob(C)}\mathcal{C}^F[A,B]=\{F(f):F(A) \rightarrow F(B),~f \in \mathcal{C}[X,Y],~X,Y \in \mathrm{Ob}(\mathcal{C})\}CF[A,B]={F(f):F(A)→F(B), f∈C[X,Y], X,Y∈Ob(C)}. No need that fff and ggg are composable since you just compose F(f)F(f)F(f) and F(g)F(g)F(g).
Though, I think these two subcategories are not very useful.
But the whole point is that F(f)∘F(g)F(f)\circ F(g)F(f)∘F(g) need not be of the form F(h)F(h)F(h) for any hhh!
You could take the subcategory generated by these morphisms, if you wanted. This is the image.

Kevin Carlson said:

But the whole point is that F(f)∘F(g)F(f)\circ F(g)F(f)∘F(g) need not be of the form F(h)F(h)F(h) for any hhh!

Ok, so the third category doesn't make sense. But in the second one you're doing F(f)∘F(g)F(f) \circ F(g)F(f)∘F(g) where fff and ggg are composable.
So that F(f)∘F(g)=F(f∘g)F(f) \circ F(g)=F(f \circ g)F(f)∘F(g)=F(f∘g).
No, sorry.
The second one being CF(A,B)={F(f), f∈C(A,B)}C_F(A,B)=\{F(f), f\in C(A,B)\}CF​(A,B)={F(f), f∈C(A,B)}?

It works if you write this:
CF[A,B]={F(f),f:A→B, such that F(f):F(A)→F(B)}\mathcal{C}_F[A,B]=\{F(f), f:A \rightarrow B, \text{ such that }F(f):F(A) \rightarrow F(B)\}CF​[A,B]={F(f),f:A→B, such that F(f):F(A)→F(B)}
You can quotient CCC by the congruence f:A→B∼g:A→Bf:A\to B\sim g:A\to Bf:A→B∼g:A→B if F(f)=F(g),F(f)=F(g),F(f)=F(g), sure. The "such that" statement you wrote doesn't seem meaningful.
Yes, it doesn't make sense.
I guess this is the factorization of FFF as a bijective-on-objects-and-full functor followed by a faithful functor.
But for sure it again doesn't require FFF to be an endofunctor.

Kevin Carlson said:

The second one being CF(A,B)={F(f), f∈C(A,B)}C_F(A,B)=\{F(f), f\in C(A,B)\}CF​(A,B)={F(f), f∈C(A,B)}?

But so, this one works?
You have F(f):F(A)→F(B)F(f):F(A) \rightarrow F(B)F(f):F(A)→F(B), F(g):F(B)→F(C)F(g):F(B) \rightarrow F(C)F(g):F(B)→F(C) and you're just doing F(g)∘F(f)F(g) \circ F(f)F(g)∘F(f).
Yes, as I said, this is the (bijective on object+full , faithful) factorization

$$\mathcal{C}^F[A,B]=\{F(f):F(A) \rightarrow F(B),~f \in \mathcal{C}[X,Y],~X,Y \in \mathrm{Ob}(\mathcal{C})\}$$. No need that $$f$$ and $$g$$ are composable since you just compose $$F(f)$$ and $$F(g)$$.
`````
And I think this one also works.
I can't read that one.
Isn't that the same third one we saw doesn't work a minute ago?

Jean-Baptiste Vienney said:

fosco said:

Jean-Baptiste Vienney said:

Kevin Carlson said:

The second version won't work, since images of functors are not always subcategories.

What do you mean? F(f)∘F(g)=F(f∘g)F(f) \circ F(g)=F(f \circ g)F(f)∘F(g)=F(f∘g), where is the issue?

The issue is that if $$f,g$ are composable then Ff,FgFf, FgFf,Fg are; not viceversa. For example, take a constant functor onto a single object, f,gf,gf,g in two disconnected components of the domain category...

CF[A,B]={F(f):F(A)→F(B), f∈C[X,Y], X,Y∈Ob(C)}\mathcal{C}^F[A,B]=\{F(f):F(A) \rightarrow F(B),~f \in \mathcal{C}[X,Y],~X,Y \in \mathrm{Ob}(\mathcal{C})\}CF[A,B]={F(f):F(A)→F(B), f∈C[X,Y], X,Y∈Ob(C)}.
Yeah, that continues not to work for the same reason it didn't work last time you agreed it doesn't work.
You can compose F(f)∘F(g)F(f)\circ F(g)F(f)∘F(g) all you want but you won't get something of the form F(h)F(h)F(h) in general.
Ok, I see.
For my defense, the second version I wrote at the beginning works just fine and then I tried to modify it in ways which don't work anymore because you told me that this second version didn't work.
Yeah, you're right, I misread your second version at first.

The way this issue (C∈Cat0̸  ⟹  FC∈Cat0\sf C\in Cat_0\not\implies\mathit{F}C\in Cat_0C∈Cat0​⟹FC∈Cat0​) for F:C→DF:\mathsf{C\to D}F:C→D is fixed in forming a [[category algebra]] (where FC0={ ∗ }\mathcal{F}\mathsf{C}_0=\set*FC0​={∗}) is to have Ff∘Fg:=0Ff\circ Fg:=0Ff∘Fg:=0 a sink morphism 0=0∘h=h∘0 ∀h∈D10=0\circ h=h\circ 0~\forall h\in \mathsf{D}_10=0∘h=h∘0 ∀h∈D1​, whenever dom(f)≠cod(g)dom(f)\neq cod(g)dom(f)=cod(g)

Is there a reason to not do something like that here? You end up with a unique sink for every homset, s.t. 0xy∘0yz=0xz0_{xy}\circ 0_{yz}=0_{xz}0xy​∘0yz​=0xz​. It seems like the "smallest" category generated by FC\mathcal{F}\mathsf{C}FC in some sense. I've probably just described some kind of named closure. :)
Yeah, I want to work with categories, not algebras. And your category algebras don't look much like categories, unless you make them into categories with a single object.

I apologize for the sloppiness with the codomain. It's fine to not want to use it, and it is algebraic in spirit, but what I have described is a category (Ed: when D\sf DD is a [[gaunt category]] ). Or rather a natural transformation taking F:C→D  ⟹  F(0):C→D(0)F:{\sf C\to D}\implies F^{(0)}:{\sf C\to D^{(0)}}F:C→D⟹F(0):C→D(0), where the codomain of F(0)F^{(0)}F(0) has D\sf DD as a faithfully included wide subcategory, and has a unique sink morphism adjoined for every homset of D\sf DD. (The sinks form their own thin/posetal subcategory, excluded only the identities.) I'll do some digging and see if there is a name for it.

But it seems like you found a way to make what you're doing work. So I won't distract you unless you want to discuss it more.

Ok, so you say that if F:C→DF:\mathcal{C} \rightarrow \mathcal{D}F:C→D is a functor, then you can define a category CF\mathcal{C}^FCF as follows:

  • Ob(CF):=Ob(C)\mathrm{Ob}(\mathcal{C}^F):=\mathrm{Ob}(\mathcal{C})Ob(CF):=Ob(C)
  • CF[A,B]:={F(f):F(A)→F(B),f∈C[X,Y], X,Y∈C}⊔{undefinedA,B:F(A)→F(B)}\mathcal{C}^F[A,B]:=\{F(f):F(A) \rightarrow F(B), f \in \mathcal{C}[X,Y],~X,Y \in \mathcal{C}\} \sqcup \{\mathrm{undefined}_{A,B}:F(A) \rightarrow F(B)\}CF[A,B]:={F(f):F(A)→F(B),f∈C[X,Y], X,Y∈C}⊔{undefinedA,B​:F(A)→F(B)}

  • If v∈CF[B,C]v \in \mathcal{C}^F[B,C]v∈CF[B,C] and u∈CF[A,B]u \in \mathcal{C}^F[A,B]u∈CF[A,B], then:
    (a) v∘CFu:=v∘uv \circ^{\mathcal{C}^F} u := v \circ uv∘CFu:=v∘u if v=F(g)v=F(g)v=F(g) for some ggg and u=F(f)u=F(f)u=F(f) for some fff such that the codomain of fff is equal to the domain of ggg,
    (b) v∘CFu:=undefinedA,Cv \circ^{\mathcal{C}^F} u:=\mathrm{undefined}_{A,C}v∘CFu:=undefinedA,C​ if there doesn't exist any f,gf,gf,g satisfying v=F(g)v=F(g)v=F(g) and u=F(f)u=F(f)u=F(f), and such that the codomain of fff is equal to the domain of ggg,
    (c) v∘CFundefinedA,B:=undefinedA,Cv \circ^{\mathcal{C}^F} \mathrm{undefined}_{A,B} := \mathrm{undefined}_{A,C}v∘CFundefinedA,B​:=undefinedA,C​
    (d) undefinedB,C∘CFu:=undefinedA,C\mathrm{undefined}_{B,C} \circ^{\mathcal{C}^F} u:=\mathrm{undefined}_{A,C}undefinedB,C​∘CFu:=undefinedA,C​

  • idACF=idF(A)\mathrm{id}_{A}^{\mathcal{C}_F}=\mathrm{id}_{F(A)}idACF​​=idF(A)​

Fine, that's interesting.
The issue is that I believe this is not necessarily a category because I think the identity will not always be unital.

I mean: it looks like sometimes postcomposing a morphism uuu (or precomposing a morphism vvv) by the identity could return undefinedA,C\mathrm{undefined}_{A,C}undefinedA,C​ instead of uuu (instead of vvv).

Note sure whether this will help @Jean-Baptiste Vienney , but your two constructions seem to be related as follows.

Your functor F:C→CF:\mathcal{C} \to \mathcal{C}F:C→C defines a natural transformation:

F0:Obj(C)→Obj(C)F_0:\mathsf{Obj}(\mathcal{C}) \to \mathsf{Obj}(\mathcal{C})F0​:Obj(C)→Obj(C)
F1:Arr(C)→Arr(C)F_1:\mathsf{Arr}(\mathcal{C}) \to \mathsf{Arr}(\mathcal{C})F1​:Arr(C)→Arr(C)

compatible with identities, source, targets, compositions, etc.

It seems that your first construction is pulling back the structure of C\mathcal{C}C along F0:Obj(C)→Obj(C)F_0:\mathsf{Obj}(\mathcal{C}) \to \mathsf{Obj}(\mathcal{C})F0​:Obj(C)→Obj(C). This gives you a new category CF\mathcal{C}_FCF​ that gives you the following factorization of FFF:

C→aCF→bC\mathcal{C} \mathop{\to}\limits^{a} \mathcal{C}_F \mathop{\to}\limits^{b} \mathcal{C}C→aCF​→bC

The morphism aaa should be induced by universal maps for the cones formed by FFF and the structure of C\mathcal{C}C. You can now use image factorizations on the components of morphism aaa to form the following factorization:

C→a0CF→a1CF\mathcal{C} \mathop{\to}\limits^{a_0} \mathcal{C}^F \mathop{\to}\limits^{a_1} \mathcal{C}_FC→a0​CF→a1​CF​

The two constructions seem to be related to the concept of weak [[Cartesian morphisms]], where your fibration would be C↦Obj(C)\mathcal{C} \mapsto \mathsf{Obj}(\mathcal{C})C↦Obj(C) and an obvious Cartesian morphism would be b:CF→Cb:\mathcal{C}_F \to \mathcal{C}b:CF​→C. I am wondering whether the arrow b∘a1:CF→Cb \circ a_1:\mathcal{C}^F \to \mathcal{C}b∘a1​:CF→C is Cartesian is some sense too.
Is aaa doing a(f)=F(f)a(f)=F(f)a(f)=F(f)?
I don't understand what you mean by "universal maps for the cones ..."
That would be bbb that has this property
I think bbb is doing b(f)=fb(f)=fb(f)=f, no?

For example, you construct source and target of CF\mathcal{C}_FCF​ by pulling back the map (s,t):Arr(C)→Obj(C)×Obj(C)(s,t):\mathsf{Arr}(\mathcal{C}) \to \mathsf{Obj}(\mathcal{C}) \times \mathsf{Obj}(\mathcal{C})(s,t):Arr(C)→Obj(C)×Obj(C) along F0×F0F_0 \times F_0F0​×F0​. The pullback gives you a source and target

(s′,t′):Arr(CF)→Obj(C)×Obj(C)(s',t'):\mathsf{Arr}(\mathcal{C}_F) \to \mathsf{Obj}(\mathcal{C})\times \mathsf{Obj}(\mathcal{C})(s′,t′):Arr(CF​)→Obj(C)×Obj(C)

where Arr(CF)={(a,f,b) ∣ (a,b) in Obj(C) and f:F(a)→F(b)}\mathsf{Arr}(\mathcal{C}_F) = \{(a,f,b)~|~(a,b) \textrm{ in } \mathsf{Obj}(\mathcal{C})\textrm{ and }f:F(a) \to F(b)\}Arr(CF​)={(a,f,b) ∣ (a,b) in Obj(C) and f:F(a)→F(b)}
The pullback square defines bbb, and if you look at the map at the bottom of that square, it should be F0×F0F_0\times F_0F0​×F0​ (representing the mapping F0F_0F0​ on source and target separately)
Ah, my bad, I realized I misread your message -- yes, a(f)=F1(f)a(f) = F_1(f)a(f)=F1​(f)
but b(X)=F0(X)b(X) = F_0(X)b(X)=F0​(X)

Jean-Baptiste Vienney said:

I don't understand what you mean by "universal maps for the cones ..."

Basically, the universal maps induced by the pullbacks to form aaa

Jean-Baptiste Vienney said:

I mean: it looks like sometimes postcomposing a morphism uuu (or precomposing a morphism vvv) by the identity could return undefinedA,C\mathrm{undefined}_{A,C}undefinedA,C​ instead of uuu (instead of vvv).

Thank you for catching that; the problem comes if FFF collapses two objects either of which has automorphisms, without collapsing the autos themselves. I’m looking back at my notes and I misremembered some stuff. But it’s getting late here. I will try again tomorrow.

Okay, couldn’t sleep! What I was suggesting only works if the codomain of FFF is a [[gaunt category]]; all isos are identities. This is quite a severe restriction for me to forget! Sorry for wasting your time, and thanks for the sanity check; my memory is just shot lately.
I hadn't known the term "gaunt category". I enjoyed this jargonesque definition: a gaunt category is a skeletal category whose core is thin.
